results.snippet: Now it's the script that has Chinatown leaders complaining about ''The Corruptor,'' an OLIVER STONE film. Some scenes are scheduled to be filmed there in May. Yesterday, 30 Chinatown leaders gathered at the Fifth Precinct station house to denounce...

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON with JANE H. LII

results.lead_paragraph: Now it's the script that has Chinatown leaders complaining about ''The Corruptor,'' an OLIVER STONE film. Some scenes are scheduled to be filmed there in May. Yesterday, 30 Chinatown leaders gathered at the Fifth Precinct station house to denounce the script, which focuses on a corrupt Chinese officer who patronizes prostitutes, accepts bribes from underworld bosses and gives them advance notice of gambling raids. They also objected to descriptions of gang wars in the script. ''We have worked hard with the police to finally erase this image of Chinatown,'' said STEVEN WONG, who represents a number of Chinatown organizations. Mr. Stone's spokeswoman would not comment.

results.abstract: Time magazine's giant celebrity party at Radio City Music Hall described (S)

headline.main: For the American Century, A Party Just as Grandiose

results.snippet: IT promised to be the 1990's version of Truman Capote's Black and White Ball -- a party so exclusive in its selective inclusivity that it becomes an instant social index -- an A-list of an era. And Time magazine's lavish 75th anniversary gala didn't...
results.lead_paragraph: IT promised to be the 1990's version of Truman Capote's Black and White Ball -- a party so exclusive in its selective inclusivity that it becomes an instant social index -- an A-list of an era. And Time magazine's lavish 75th anniversary gala didn't disappoint. Forget the last so-called party of the decade -- the Versace event at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This was the bash of the pre-millennium. Some wags dubbed it Walter's bar mitzvah, referring to Walter Isaacson, the magazine's managing editor, who served as unofficial emcee. But that doesn't do justice to an evening that in its mix of real and surreal, politesse and politics, could have been scripted by Tom Stoppard. One newspaper editor glanced at the multi-tiered, concentric red dining space that had been erected over the seats at Radio City Music Hall and likened it to a media version of purgatory. (The floorboards were virtually bulletproof, and courtesy of President Clinton's security detail, the building was patrolled by a pack of bomb-sniffing dogs, and there were sharpshooters mounted on the roof.)

results.abstract: Veteran inventor Robert E Fulton Jr, age 89, recalls flying automobile he designed in early 1950's, interview; photo in Newton, Conn, with his Airphibian (S)

headline.main: Invention, in All Its Beguiling Varieties

results.snippet: WHAT powers the life of an inventor like Robert E. Fulton Jr.? An all-weather curiosity fueled by an unabating desire to create that which is useful. Throughout his 89 years, the Newtown resident has approached the impossible and proved it otherwise....
results.lead_paragraph: WHAT powers the life of an inventor like Robert E. Fulton Jr.? An all-weather curiosity fueled by an unabating desire to create that which is useful. Throughout his 89 years, the Newtown resident has approached the impossible and proved it otherwise. Case in point: his federally approved flying automobile. You've never heard of the Airphibian? That's hard to believe if you were alive and old enough to read in the early 1950's because Mr. Fulton and his flying car were profiled in every popular magazine of the era. He logged more than 100,000 miles in test flights, going cross-country numerous times, and showcasing his invention in Canada, Mexico, Britain and the Netherlands. Inspectors for the Civil Aeronautics Administration liked the design so well they placed an order for 10 Airphibians they intended to use to get to work.

results.abstract: Anne-Marie Schiro reviews fall collections of Japanese designers Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake and Rei Kawakubo that were shown in Paris during week; photos (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; The Deconstructivists: Summing Up the Parts

results.snippet: The Japanese designers who showed here this week lived up to their reputation as the most experimental in the world. There was hardly a conventional cut or an ordinary coat or dress in the fall collections of Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake or Rei...
results.lead_paragraph: The Japanese designers who showed here this week lived up to their reputation as the most experimental in the world. There was hardly a conventional cut or an ordinary coat or dress in the fall collections of Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake or Rei Kawakubo for Comme des Garcons. Mr. Watanabe described his clothing, made of khaki or gray melton felt, as ''nonconstructed,'' and indeed he employed few of the dressmaking and tailoring techniques normally used to construct clothes.

results.abstract: Alan Alda discusses his live interview with American astronaut Andrew K Thomas aboard Mir space station for Public Broadcasting Service; photo (S)
results.snippet: ''Looks like NASA,'' ALAN ALDA said as he walked in, but it was not Mission Control, only a television control room on West 42d Street.     Mr. Alda was there to interview ANDREW S. K. THOMAS, the American astronaut aboard the Mir space station, for...

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON with KIMBERLY STEVENS and PHOEBE HOBAN

results.lead_paragraph: ''Looks like NASA,'' ALAN ALDA said as he walked in, but it was not Mission Control, only a television control room on West 42d Street. Mr. Alda was there to interview ANDREW S. K. THOMAS, the American astronaut aboard the Mir space station, for the Public Broadcasting Service. The interview was carried live on the Internet, a first for PBS. Ordinary television viewers will have to wait until it is broadcast on ''Scientific American Frontiers'' next year.

results.abstract: One of Russia's most prestigious military institutions, Frunze Naval Academy, is first and only naval academy in country to accept female cadet; Cadet Lyudmila Yolshina says she was not greeted with anything like hostility that drove Shannon Faulkner from The Citadel after only one week; she says she was told to report any problems to superiors, and her fellow cadets fear consequences if they harass her; mostly, she seems surrounded by amused condescension; but cadets and faculty of Frunze draw line at her dream of serving on combat ship; Russian women have extraordinary record of combat bravery in wartime, yet they are relegated to lowly support position in rear during peacetime; Yolchina was accepted at Funze only after writing letter to Pres Boris N Yeltsin and Defense Min Igor D Sergeyev, imploring them to let her continue family tradition of naval service; photos (M)

headline.main: St. Petersburg Journal; Russian Woman Sails Solo in a Sea of Cadets

results.snippet: Except for peeling paint, little has changed at the Frunze Naval Academy since it was founded by Peter the Great in 1715.    Despite hard times, the naval academy, an elegant ocher-colored palace on the banks of the Neva, remains one of Russia's most...
results.lead_paragraph: Except for peeling paint, little has changed at the Frunze Naval Academy since it was founded by Peter the Great in 1715. Despite hard times, the naval academy, an elegant ocher-colored palace on the banks of the Neva, remains one of Russia's most prestigious military institutions. There are still six applicants for every position, and traditions are jealously guarded.
